Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council, Ottawa, Canada

respStmt.resp: Post-doctoral Fellow in Digital Humanities, EATS taxonomy developer and tagger

availability.p: Copyright Records of Early English Drama (REED), 2020
availability.licence: Distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) licence.

sourceDesc.p: Born digital. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

revisionDesc.change: Updated Responsibility Statements in File Description and edition number

item.title: Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources

div.p: Words are included in the Latin Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in the Oxford Latin Dictionary (OLD), as supplemented where appropriate by the Dictionary of Medieval Latin from British Sources (DML). Other works consulted can be found in the General Bibliography. Adverbs that are formed regularly from adjectives found in the OLD and DML are not included. Words with unusual spellings have been not been included if they are treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
c for t before i
cc for ct before i
-d for -t in final position
e for ae or oe
ff- for f- in initial position
addition or omission of h
variation between i and e or ar and er in medial positions, especially before another vowel
variation between de- and di- as a prefix
n for m before another nasal or a stop (eg, inp- for imp-)
intrusion of p in consonant clusters mm, mn, ms, or mt
doubling of single consonants or vice versa

Where the same word occurs in spellings which differ according to the list above, the most common spelling is treated as standard and used for the headword. We have conformed to the practice of the OLD as regards 'i/j' and 'u/v' variation: in this glossary only the letter forms 'i' and 'u' are used. If a noun of the first declension appears only with a genitive singular in '-ae,' that spelling is used in the head form, otherwise the ML '-e' is used.

Nouns are listed by nominative, genitive, and gender; adjectives by the endings of the nominative singular or, in the case of adjectives of one ending, by the nominative and genitive; verbs by their principal parts.

Words have been included in the Anglo-French Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in either the Collins-Robert French Dictionary or in the Anglo-Norman Dictionary Online (AND) or cannot be easily found there in the spelling in which they occur in the text. Other works consulted can be found in the General Bibliography. Words with unusual spellings have been not been included if they are treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
doubling of single consonants
singling of double consonants
elision of preceding de, la, le, or ne with words beginning with a vowel or h
variability of vowel or diphthongs preceding -r (eg, our for er, ir for er)
omission or addition of h in initial position
au for a or al
addition or omission of final e
-ent for -ant in final position and vice versa
-es for -ez or vice versa in final position
oe or oi for e or ei
ou for o
-tz or -z for -s or -ce in final position
y for i

Words, including place names and other proper names, easily recognizable from the English are not glossed (eg, 'Hector de troyes,' 'hire'). Nouns are designated n f (feminine), n m (masculine), or n where the gender cannot be determined from context.

Words have been included in the English Glossary if they are not found with the required sense in the Oxford English Dictionary Online (OEDO) or cannot be easily found there in the spelling in which they appear in the text. Other works consulted can be found in the General Bibliography. Words with unusual spellings have not been included if they have been treated in the text as scribal errors and footnoted, or if they are the result of the following common spelling variations alone:
doubling of single consonants and vice versa
a/ai/ay
a/au
ar/er
c/s
ea/e/ei
e/i
ie/e(e)
i/j
i/y
oa/o/oo
o/ou
o/u
s/z
sch/sh
u/v
u/w
w for u as a vowel
y- in initial position for th or þ
presence or absence of final -e
medial d for th (eg, fader for father)
plurals ending in -n (eg, shoon for shoes)
elision of the with words beginning with a vowel or h (thandes for the hands)
fusion of indefinite article with following noun or adjective (eg, aboke for a book)
interchangeable vowels in unstressed syllables (eg, aftor or aftyr for after)
past tense verbs ending in -t (eg, rackt for racked)
Obsolete or nonce compounds are not glossed unless they are particulary obscure or difficult.

The capitalization of headwords conforms to modern usage. A word appearing in several noteworthy spellings is normally entered under the one most often found in the text or else – when two spellings are equally or nearly equally common – under the one nearer modern usage, but a marginally less common spelling may be preferred to keep related forms together in the entry order of the glossary. Other spellings are entered in their alphabetical places and cross-referenced to the main entry. In the alphabetical order of the glossary 'þ' follows 't' and 'ȝ' follows 'y.' Where the definition repeats the headword in a different spelling, the latter is normally the entry spelling in OEDO and further information can be found there. When that form is itself an archaism or ambiguous, a further brief definition usually follows. Any further citation of an authority or other succinct account of the glossarian's reasoning appears within square brackets at the end of the entry.

entry.sense: baptist, here, as title of St John, beside the usual baptista
St Bettelin (dates unknown), patron of Stafford
bearward, beside the more usual berewardus [DML]
in CL fall, a falling or throwing down; here the form has apparently been confused with caseus, -i n m cheese
to certify; as a legal term, to certify formally, eg, the truth of a statement, compliance with an order, or the performance of an obligation
one who plays the cithera; here likely a harper

hair; by extension, wig; comibus abl, in error, or of collateral 3rd decl form
[DML, OLD coma]
coomb, a dry measure of capacity, equal to four bushels, or half a quarter [OEDO coomb | comb, n.1]
piper, possibly a generic term for one who plays a wind instrument
homage, here the jury of a manorial court [cp OEDO homage, n. 2.]
in CL a light early morning refreshment, breakfast; in AL sometimes a more substantial festive meal; gentaculum, -i
justicar, a royal judge, usually of a superior court
young; as subst a youth, young person, in CL a young adult; here, a boy; see episcopus
sheet or blanket, here a sheet worn during ritual penance [cp OEDO sheet, n.1 1.c]
entertainment, ‘play,’ of an unspecified kind, not necessarily dramatic [see also DML ludus]
of or pertaining to St Michael; see also terminus
a servant; here likely a minstrel
in CL a 3 stringed lute, here evidently a bowed stringed instrument
in CL bread; here the form has apparently been confused with pannus, -i n m cloth, tablecloth; panys
of or pertaining to a parish
a teacher of children [cp DML paedotribes]
drink, here weak ale as distinct from ceruisia
promoted, used of a proceeding against a person in a church court moved or initiated by someone other than the court itself or a person authorized to make presentment
Athenian deputies in Amphictyonic council (from Greek πυλαγόραι)
the act of giving back, restoring, delivering again
in CL hedge or fence; here the form has apparently been confused with caepa, -e n f onion
likely harper; perhaps originally in error for citharista
turnspit, one who turns a spit, var of veruvertor [DML]; ueriueter
warrener, here likely an officer employed to protect game on the commons on behalf of the king
in CL, an actor; sense widening in ML, here an entertainer, or performer of some kind unspecified [see histrio DML, OLD]
to the; used to introduce a vernacular word in an otherwise Latin passage

entry.form: bouche in phr estre a bouche en court, estre a bouche de court
entry.sense: to have an allowance for food [AND bouche]
possibly Bourbon, name of a French aristocratic family, here as attr, in the style associated with that family or a member of it, or with the historic French province of Bourbonnais
charger, horse ridden in charging a combatant [AND destrer]
slice (of bread); as an element in the names of various dishes, prepared in slices
raisins of Corinth, ie, currants [see OEDO currant]
to presage, foretell; typically used to denote an ominous foretelling, but here used in a positive sense [OEDO abode v]
of a type made in Bruges [OEDO a prep.2 8; Bruges n 1.b,c]
act; here possibly an entertainment of some kind
anent, before, in the sight of [OEDO anent prep II]
Armorical; an inhabitant of Armorica, here likely a Breton
raised or levied (money, troops, etc) [OEDO araise v 3]; aresed, arreised, arreysed
hastler, one who roasts meat on a spit, one who turns a spit; asselares pl
antic, fantastic tracery or sculpture(?) [OEDO antic adj and n B.n.1.a], or possibly antique, a relic of ancient art, or of bygone days(?) [OEDO antique adj and n B.n.2]
bauble, a baton used as a fool's mock emblem of office
ban, a public proclamation [OEDO n.1]; bayne
banner poles, here poles meant to hold ensigns or flags borne in processions [OEDO banner n 1.2.a]
bank; possibly a bench, or a set or array of similar items [OEDO bank n.2 1, 6.a]
Bartlemastide, festivities associated with St Bartholomew’s Day
bearward; barod(?), bererd, berewood, berherd, berode, berrerd
part of a fool's attire, a baton used as a mock emblem of office [OEDO bauble n 4]
baldric, a belt worn across the breast and used to support items such as swords or musical instruments
bailiff; baalife, baylef, baylief, bayly; baylyespl
bell, here to be tied around a Morris dancer’s knees; bel

beer; beare; ber;
berman n beerman, a man who serves beer
bears, here understood to be accompanied by bearwards
to beshrew, to invoke evil upon, to wish (one) all that is bad; an imprecatory expression [OEDO beshrew v 3.b]
scullion or kitchen servant, or a servant who holds a similar position in an army(?) [OEDO blackguards n A.I.2.a, b]; blacke gardspl
to remain somewhere for a long period of time (?)
blubbered; flooded with tears [OEDO blubbered adj]
boat hire; funds paid to hire a boat
buckram, a linen or cotton fabric
branch, here likely a branch used to construct a bower for a king play; bogh; boughe; bow; see also king
soup,here possibly broth or stock [OEDO bukenade]
bower, here a space artificially enclosed with branches; bowerrye; bowrie; in phr Robin Hoodes bower a bower constructed during Robin Hood games from which Robin Hood presided
broach; a spit used to cook meat [OEDO broach n.1 2.a]; broatche
the Broad Eye, a windmill in Stafford; broadey
board, here used to construct a stage
bushing, the act of constructing a bower; bussheyng
a canopy in a design or colour representative of a particular household, title, etc [OEDO estate n 4.c]
cap-making, the cap maker's trade [OEDO capping n 2]; cappinge
a set of playing cards [OEDO pair n.1 II.6]; geven to the cardes lost in a game (or games) of cards(?)
carriage; the act of carrying; caridge, carrege

carrying
carriing prp ; see also carege, caryour
Cain in the Genesis story of Cain and Abel; kayme
chaudon, a kind of sauce containing chopped entrails
St Crispin's Day; chryspany day; chryspian day; chryspiane day; crispiany daie; cryspyany day
cognizance, a badge or device of recognition [OEDO cognizance | cognisance n III.5.a]; cognizance
the kings of Cologne, or wise men of the East from the Christmas story, so called because a shrine in Cologne Cathedral purportedly contained their relics [OEDO cologne n b]
Cologne lute; a lute made or acquired in Cologne
commonality; used here in the sense of community, commonwealth, and likely also common people [OEDO commonality n 1.a, 2]
the legal right to pasture livestock [OEDO common n.1 6]
course, the pursuit of game [OEDO course n 7.a]; coorsse
counterfeit; here, someone pretending to travel as a jester with a noble patron or possibly someone with a physical disability or deformity [OEDO counterfeit adj and n A.8, B.4]

of little or no account, ordinary;
in phr coursse money petty cash (?) [OEDO coarse adj 1.a, b], [MED cours adj (a)]; course money
a kind of linen cloth [OEDO crest | cress n 3]
cross house, ie, church house; crosse howse
conduct, steer; here used intransitively to refer to a ship's capacity to be steered rightly [OEDO cond | cund v]
curl; here, possibly a wig (?) [OEDO curle v.1 2]
dancing silver; money paid for dancing; dawnsyng siluer

entry.form: distreyne, distreane, distreine v inf, pr
entry.sense: distrain, to constrain or punish a person by seizing their goods [OEDO distrain v II.7.a]
a decayed piece of timber [OEDO doddered adj 1.a]
dwelling (?) in phr dowellyng money dwelling money, payment for temporary lodging (?)
drum; here used to refer to a drummer
dizzard; a jester or foolish person
essoined; excused for absence[OEDO essoin v 2];
estreated, (of a fine, forfeiture) exacted, enforced [OEDO estreat v2]
falchion, a single-edged sword; fawchones pl
fee-farm; here likely used to denote document(s) establishing the perpetual fixed rent of an estate for an owner and his heirs [OEDO fee-farm n, fee-simple n]
feleness, greatness of number or quantity [OEDO fele adv (and n.) and adj.2]
furbelows, flounces, pleated borders on gowns or petticoats
flat-cap, one who wears a flat cap; perhaps here an apprentice (?) [OEDO flat-cap n 2]
a cloth made of flax, a coarse fibred plant [OEDO flax n]
gurgeons, coarse refuse from flour, pollards; goriones
jerkin; gearcken, gearken, gercken, gerkenes pl
gear, here likely apparel used in the performance of a play
great bell, the largest bell in a church tower
in total [OEDO great adj P2.b.(a)]; of greate of the sum total (?)
hallows, saints; in phrall halewyn parish All Hallows parish
halfpenny, halfpence (?); a coin worth half the value of a penny, or a collection of these coins [OEDO halfpenny n]; halpennsse
likely a shortening of Wolverhampton; hamptonn
knight harbinger, a title given to one responsible for purveying lodgings for an army, royal procession, etc, or for setting up a campground
hawk's bell; a bell fastened on the leg of a hunting hawk [OEDOhawk's bell | hawk-bell n]
mean wretches(?) [OEDO hayne n], or heinous(?)
hair, here a wig attached to a cap as part of a costume
jail delivery, the release of prisoners from jail
St John's Day, possibly in error for 'Iohns'
contagion, possibly with a play on 'incantation'
empanel, a list of members of a jury [OEDO empanel n]
jerks; thrusts, pushes, pulls, or twists with sudden movements [OEDO jerk v.1 2.a]

entry.form: kinge n in phr kinge ale, kingal, kingale, kingalle, kingeale, kyng ale, kyngale, kyngalle, kynge ale, kyngeale
entry.sense: king ale, an inversion of order event in which a king — typically a local young man or farmer — was appointed to preside over the festival; kyng game, kynges game, king play, kynges play, kyng play synonymous with king ale; in phr king halle, kyng halle king hall, likely a bower built for the king of the king ale
leads; sheets or strips of metal used to cover a roof [OEDO lead n.1 7.a]
liberal arts, the branches of learning forming the trivium (grammar, logic, rhetoric) and quadrivium (arithmetic, geometry, music, astronomy) in medieval education [OEDO science n 3.a]
belonging, here used in the sense of 'attached' to refer to caps with wigs
lop, to cut off branches, leaves, etc, to trim
lining, used here for a doublet
lined, used here to indicate that a rudder is equipped with new lines(?)
in malkin attire, dressed untidily; used here quasi-adverbially
May's gown, a gown belonging to a character in a May game(?)
minstrel; mennystrelle; mensterell; mensterlle; menstreel; mentrelle; minestrell; mynesryle; mystrelle
mouth, here, a mouthpiece for a trumpet
music; here used to refer to a musician or group of musicians
musician; mosition; muscon; musitan; musithian; mussisione; mussissien; musycan; musycon; musysion; mutitian; mysysion
miscontent, used here to refer to an instance of discontent, dissatisfaction, or annoyance [OEDO miscontent n]
an act of misdemeanour, an actionable offense of misconduct committed by a misdemeanant [OEDO misdemeanant n 1]
nigh; in adv phr ny vppon near or close to
obit, a gift made to pay for a commemorative service for a deceased person [OEDO obit, n.1 2.b, 2.c]
occupyings, used here in the sense of (habitual) practice, carrying on [OEDO occupy v 2.a; occupying n 1]
honour, here, a manorial estate, the manor itself
eaves, the edge of a forest; oveis; oves
paned, made up of panes, here, of cloth
pavane, a kind of stately court dance; here music written for this dance [OEDO pavane n 2]
piece, used here to indicate a quantity of fruit(?)[OEDO piece n etymology]
picking, used here to refer to wood that people have picked up(?)
point, tagged ribbon or cord used to attach hose to a doublet, lace a garment, fasten a shoe, etc [OEDO point n.1 II.23.a]; poynte
viscera, the interior organs of an animal
pottle; as a unit of capacity, equal to half a gallon
pot sugars; a form of sugar suitable for dissolving in a pot of liquid(?)
in primis; a Latinism signifying first, in the first place
pied coat, a fool's coat, typically a coat with variegated colour [OEDO pied adj A.1.b and S2]
pinked, of cloth, ornamented with eyelets or other perforations; pyncket
pin, here likely used to fasten badges to clothing as proof of admission
quartern, a quarter of a pound [OEDO quartern n.2 3.b]; quartren
quoit, a ring thrown at a target for sport [OEDO quoit n 1, 2.a, 2.b]
routing; shouting, bellowing, crying out [OEDO rout v.4 1]
riddle book, a book of riddles(?)
rifling, the act of offering a prize in a raffle [OEDO rifle v.2]
roe, a species of small deer
rosin, a kind of powder, used here for fire-making
likely one of several hamlets known as Ridware: Pipe Ridware, Mavesyn Ridware, or Hamstall Ridware
sars, fish of the sparoid genus Sargus [OEDO]
sambocade, a fritter flavoured with elder flowers [OEDO]
Cerberus, the mythological multi-headed guard dog of Hades, here a prop or costume used in a play
attendant responsible for guiding or conducting people to the Great Chamber, Presence Chamber, or other chamber for audience [OEDO show v 16]
sheet roll (?), a record or list [OEDO roll n.1 I.1.a, b]

sense.hi: precise meaning unclear; possibly an imitative or onomatopoeic nonce word or portmanteau of 'smirked' and 'snorted'

entry.sense: summer game; a festival, sport, or entertainment held in the summer
stale ale; old and strong ale [OEDO stale adj.1 1]
state body, the collective population of a town, city, state, etc; especially that portion of the population involved in its government [OEDO body n 13.a]
stairs, in n ph payer of stayers a flight of stairs or a portable set of steps [OEDO stair, pair n.1., 9.]
stoops, pillars or posts used by performers (?) [OEDO stoop n.1 1.a]
possibly an error for, or variant of stuff
stick, a length of fabric [OEDO stick n.3 1]
a white suit worn by a player to appear naked
a performer on a tabret [OEDO tabret n 2]; taberat
Tantalus, the Greek mythological figure, here a play character
tapnet, a basket made of rushes in which figs are imported; also used as a measure of quantity [OEDO tapnet | topnet n A.a]
tent, a Spanish wine [OEDO tent n.4]
the increase, the profit; thencreys see also encrays
a tree trunk, likely used for a maypole
trunks, a game resembling bagatelle; tronkes[OEDOtrunkn 16]
unbaited, used here to describe the flesh of a bull that has not been baited
Vortimer, son of Vortigern, here a play character
Venetian hose; Venesons, Venesyones, Venesyons, Venysiones
verjuice; vegews; vergeous; vergeows; verious; veriouse; verius
usually a keyed musical instrument with plural form refering to one instrument, but here possibly the keyboard(s) to an organ (?); virginalls; virginialls
wearing, used here in the sense of use, wear and tear
wit, to know; in phr to wete to wit, that is to say
household officials, servants, or attendants; specific duties are unknown [OEDO yeoman n C3.a]; yemen of the mayell
yeoman waits; household officials, servants, or attendants charged with keeping watch [OEDO yeoman n C3.a]
a household official, servant, or attendant; specific duties are unknown
into, unto [OEDO into prep and adj 16]
household officials, servants, or attendants charged with procuring drink [OEDO yeoman n C3.a]; yemen of the bottells; yemen of the flagenes
household officials, servants, or attendants charged with maintaining a pantry, or with providing or serving food and drink [OEDO yeoman n C3.a]
